{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3017207,"name":"jfitz0807","username":"jfitz0807","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-05T13:36:29.696Z","cooked":"

We‚Äôre using the ThriftyBot single stage elevator with a Neo on a 6::1 gear reduction. Our winch consists of Thunderhex with our 1/8‚Äù winch rope. With the Neo on kBrake mode (blue blinking LED) while disabled, the elevator still rides up on its own due to the constant force springs. We were expecting that the Neo in brake mode would be able to hold it in place.

Any thoughts or suggestions?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-05T13:36:29.696Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":39,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":239.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"jfitz0807","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11577,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3017208,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-05T13:42:32.237Z","cooked":"

If you‚Äôre having trouble holding the arms when the only force comes from the springs, you‚Äôre going to have a heck of a time trying to hold them in the 5 seconds after your robot has been disabled when you add gravity to that.

I don‚Äôt have enough experience with the Neos, but suspect that your gear ratio is way too low. Our gear ratio is just over 100:1 on a 775pro, and does hold in brake mode.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-05T13:42:32.237Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":59.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3017215,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-05T14:42:49.352Z","cooked":"

We have 8:1 on two falcons and our brake mode is just barely not enough. You should try to I crease the gear ratio. I hear 12:1 is the minimum you want to aim for for the thrifty bot kits

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-05T14:42:49.352Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":197,"readers_count":196,"score":59.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3017220,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-05T14:57:35.019Z","cooked":"

We have 2x neo‚Äôs with a 7:1 reduction. 1 neo at that ratio isnt enough to climb, even with both brake mode isn‚Äôt enough to hold it in place. Fortunately, we designed in a ratchet mechanism from the beginning - we knew it wouldn‚Äôt be able to hold itself up after the match without it.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-05T14:57:35.019Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":51.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"Jon Stratis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7968,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 2177 Mentor, LRI, MN RPC"},"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/4","custom_user_title":"FRC 2177 Mentor, LRI, MN RPC","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3017783,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-06T20:44:17.760Z","cooked":"

AndyMark recommends 16:1 on a NEO, though that is based on their climber winch with a .787" diameter drum. Thunderhex has a 13mm or about .512. That still gets you down to a recommendation closer to 10:1 than 6:1, and that‚Äôs for the climb. Unless you are climbing to a second rung where coming down the last step doesn‚Äôt matter, I‚Äôd look to an active brake or pawl or ratchet.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-06T20:44:17.760Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":53.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/5","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3017797,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-06T21:10:52.791Z","cooked":"

We use a single falcon, with a 2 inch diameter drum and 35:1. We climb in 3 or 4 seconds to the low bar, which is good enough for us for now. AndyMark‚Äôs recommendation falls right into that same wheelhouse. Keep in mind you have to watch your current - we designed our starting gear ratio to stay below 40 amp-ish.

Later in the year we‚Äôre start getting more aggressive.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-06T21:10:52.791Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":26.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22335,"username":"GeeTwo","name":"Gus Michel II","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/6","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3017884,"name":"jfitz0807","username":"jfitz0807","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-06T22:23:14.816Z","cooked":"

We have fixed length rotating arms as part of our climb to higher bars. We plan to use an attachment from this to hold the elevator down until it‚Äôs time to climb. Thanks.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-03-06T22:23:14.816Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":33.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":404717,"topic_slug":"holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode","display_username":"jfitz0807","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11577,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/holding-spring-loaded-elevators-in-brake-mode/404717/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3017949,"name":"UnofficialForth","username":"UnofficialForth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unofficialforth/{size}/167902_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-06T23:50:21.840Z","cooked":"

Reminder to all: Brake mode just does a form of short circuiting the motor so it‚Äôs resistant to sudden/large amounts of movement. However, anything with a constant force may still move, just slowly.
